title: New York judge issues limited gag order after Trump's post about court clerk
description: 'Personal attacks (...) are unacceptable,' Judge Engoron said about a 'disparaging, untrue and personally identifying post about a member of my staff.'

title: Military recruiters in Odesa prowl at the university gates
description: In the large port city in southern Ukraine, uniformed patrols check day and night on young people enrolling in training courses to avoid being sent to the front.

title: 'If Joe Biden is the candidate of the unions, Donald Trump is the candidate of the workers'
description: While attacking electric cars, Donald Trump intends to campaign for re-election on his favorite themes: 'America first' and protectionism, writes New York correspondent Arnaud Leparmentier.

title: Kevin McCarthy no longer speaker of the US House
description: The Republican was ousted in a dramatic vote as Democrats joined with GOP critics to topple him. Rep. Patrick McHenry of North Carolina was appointed speaker pro tempore.

title: In Italy, a bus crash kills at least 20 near Venice
description: There are 15 survivors from the accident in the Mestre suburb of Venice.

title: Portugal to end tax scheme for foreigners from 2024
description: The measure has contributed to soaring house prices over the last decade.

title: Macron party plans bill to squash France bedbug 'scourge'
description: Bedbugs have in recent weeks gone from being a subject of potential derision to a contentious political issue in France.

title: France agrees to deliver military equipment to Armenia
description: Without providing any specific details, French Foreign Affairs Minister Catherine Colonna announced arms would be sent to Armenia to help strengthen their defense against Azerbaijan.

title: Australia after 'Black Summer': A slow recovery from the 2019-2020 megafires
description: 'Living after a disaster' (2/6). The Blue Mountains saw 80% of their forest cover destroyed during the 2019-2020 Australian bushfire season. Since then, nature has somewhat regenerated, but locals dread the aftermath. To better fight future blazes, they're turning to traditional Aboriginal techniques.

title: Hunter Biden pleads not guilty to gun charges
description: President Joe Biden's son has been charged with lying about his drug use in October 2018 on a form to buy a gun that he kept for about 11 days. He could face up to 25 years in prison if convicted.

title: Brazil launches investigation into one of the country’s largest banks for its role in slavery
description: Researchers point to Banco do Brasil’s responsibility in the slave trade, while associations of  slave descendants demand reparations.

title: Pro-independence president of Polynesia makes plea to UN for decolonization
description: The Polynesian president will defend his position before the United Nations on Tuesday and can count on popular support. Perceived as the most moderate within the pro-independence party, he faces pressure from more radical members.

title: Bedbugs in France: 'They can be found wherever people go'
description: Le Monde asked Jean-Michel Bérenger, an entomologist for a medical research center in Marseille, to provide answers to reader questions concerning the 'major upsurge' in bedbug infestations in the country.

title: Three killed in Bangkok mall shooting, attacker arrested
description: Hundreds of people fled the upmarket Siam Paragon mall in the heart of the Thai capital as shots rang out around 4:30 pm local time.

title: Cholera: Number of cases reported to WHO doubled between 2021 and 2022
description: The World Health Organization has published new figures on the seventh cholera pandemic. Data is incomplete due to the wide differences between countries' epidemiological capacities.

title: Tropical Storm Philippe makes landfall in Barbuda
description: The erratic storm unleashed heavy rains and flash floods in the northeast Caribbean.

title: Armenia parliament ratifies ICC founding treaty
description: Moscow, the ex-Soviet country's historic ally had warned against the decision to ratify the Rome Statue, which it qualified as 'extremely hostile.'

title: Kenya-led UN security mission to intervene in Haiti, at the request of the US
description: The Security Council on Monday approved the dispatch of a multinational force to Haiti. This intervention will be led by Kenya, a first for an African country in the Americas, and the result of a 'convergence of interests' with the United States.

title: Paris Fashion Week sets the scene, from the Château de Vincennes to Invalides
description: The major fashion houses are making their shows resonate with the Parisian venues that host them, to the point of making them a key element in their sartorial narrative.

title: Why diplomatic relations between France and Morocco have turned sour
description: 'France and Morocco: Wounds of the heart' (1/3). The first in a series of articles addressing areas of tension between the two nations looks at diplomatic frictions, and the poor personal relationship between King Mohammed VI and Emmanuel Macron.

title: Inland China caught up in the real estate crisis
description: In Xi'an, the imperial city in Shaanxi Province, many have felt the effects of the real estate crisis.

title: Poland's legislative elections: Ultraconservatives bank on brutal polarization
description: With two weeks until the polls, Jaroslaw Kaczynski's party is accusing the opposition of wanting to turn Poland into a 'second Lampedusa' and its leader, Donald Tusk, of wishing for the 'devastation of the country.'

title: California, at the forefront in the fight to protect the planet
description: In addition to a complaint filed in mid-September against five oil companies, the Californian government has enacted a law requiring major companies operating on its territory to publish their carbon footprint.

title: How Brazil's former 'hunger capital' became the most Lula-aligned city
description: Guaribas, in the state of Piaui, has established itself as a testing ground and symbol of the social policies of Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's Workers' Party, which returned to power in January.
